sn35.243:4.1: At one time the Buddha was staying in the land of the Sakyans, near Kapilavatthu in the Banyan Tree Monastery.
sn35.243:4.2: Now at that time a new town hall had recently been constructed for the Sakyans of Kapilavatthu. It had not yet been occupied by an ascetic or brahmin or any person at all.
sn35.243:4.3: Then the Sakyans of Kapilavatthu went up to the Buddha,
sn35.243:4.4: bowed, sat down to one side,
sn35.243:4.6: “Sir, a new town hall has recently been constructed for the Sakyans of Kapilavatthu. It has not yet been occupied by an ascetic or brahmin or any person at all.
sn35.243:4.7: May the Buddha be the first to use it,
sn35.243:4.8: and only then will the Sakyans of Kapilavatthu use it.
sn35.243:4.9: That would be for the lasting welfare and happiness of the Sakyans of Kapilavatthu.”
sn35.243:5.1: Then, knowing that the Buddha had accepted, the Sakyans got up from their seat, bowed, and respectfully circled the Buddha, keeping him on his right. Then they went to the new town hall,
sn35.243:5.2: where they spread carpets all over, prepared seats, set up a water jar, and placed a lamp. Then they went back to the Buddha
sn35.243:5.3: and told him of their preparations, saying:
sn35.243:5.5: Please, sir, come when you’re ready.”
sn35.243:5.6: Then the Buddha got dressed and, taking his bowl and robes, went to the new town hall together with the Saṅgha of mendicants.
sn35.243:5.7: Having washed his feet he entered the town hall and sat against the central column facing east.
sn35.243:5.8: The Saṅgha of mendicants also washed their feet, entered the town hall, and sat against the west wall facing east, with the Buddha right in front of them.
sn35.243:5.9: The Sakyans of Kapilavatthu also washed their feet, entered the town hall, and sat against the east wall facing west, with the Buddha right in front of them.
sn35.243:5.10: The Buddha spent most of the night educating, encouraging, firing up, and inspiring the Sakyans with a Dharma talk. Then he dismissed them:
sn35.243:5.13: “Yes, sir,” replied the Sakyans. They got up from their seat, bowed, and respectfully circled the Buddha, keeping him on their right, before leaving.
sn35.243:6.1: And then, soon after the Sakyans had left, the Buddha addressed Venerable Mahāmoggallāna:
sn35.243:6.2: “Moggallāna, the Saṅgha of mendicants is rid of dullness and drowsiness.
sn35.243:6.3: Give them some Dharma talk as you feel inspired.
sn35.243:6.7: And then the Buddha spread out his outer robe folded in four and lay down in the lion’s posture—on the right side, placing one foot on top of the other—mindful and aware, and focused on the time of getting up.
sn35.243:6.8: There Venerable Mahāmoggallāna addressed the mendicants:
sn35.243:6.12: “I will teach you the explanation of the corrupt and the uncorrupted.
sn35.243:6.13: Listen and pay close attention, I will speak.”
sn35.243:7.2: Take a mendicant who sees a sight with the eye. If it’s pleasant they hold on to it, but if it’s unpleasant they dislike it. They live with mindfulness of the body unestablished and their heart restricted. And they don’t truly understand the freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom where those arisen bad, unwholesome qualities cease without anything left over.
sn35.243:7.3: They hear a sound … smell an odor … taste a flavor … feel a touch …
sn35.243:7.4: cognize a phenomena with the mind. If it’s pleasant they hold on to it, but if it’s unpleasant they dislike it. They live with mindfulness of the body unestablished and a limited heart. And they don’t truly understand the freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom where those arisen bad, unwholesome qualities cease without anything left over.
sn35.243:7.5: This is called a mendicant who is corrupt when it comes to sights cognizable by the eye,
sn35.243:7.8: When a mendicant lives like this, if Māra approaches their eye he finds a vulnerability and gets hold of them.
sn35.243:7.9: If Māra approaches their ear … nose … tongue … body …
sn35.243:7.10: mind he finds a vulnerability and gets hold of them.
sn35.243:8.1: Suppose there was a house made of reeds or straw that was dried up, withered, and decrepit.
sn35.243:8.2: If a person came with a burning grass torch from the east,
sn35.243:8.8: or from anywhere, the fire would find a vulnerability, it would get a foothold.
sn35.243:8.9: In the same way, when a mendicant lives like this, if Māra approaches their eye he finds a vulnerability and gets hold of them.
sn35.243:8.10: If Māra comes in through their ear … nose … tongue … body …
sn35.243:8.11: mind he finds a vulnerability and gets hold of them.
sn35.243:8.12: When a mendicant lives like this, they’re mastered by sights,
sn35.243:8.17: and phenomena, they don’t master these things.
sn35.243:8.18: This is called a mendicant who has been mastered by sights, sounds, smells, tastes, touches, and phenomena. They’re mastered, not a master. Bad, unwholesome qualities have mastered them, which are defiled, leading to future lives, hurtful, and resulting in suffering and future rebirth, old age, and death.
sn35.243:9.2: Take a mendicant who sees a sight with the eye. If it’s pleasant they don’t hold on to it, and if it’s unpleasant they don’t dislike it. They live with mindfulness of the body established and a limitless heart. And they truly understand the freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom where those arisen bad, unwholesome qualities cease without anything left over.
sn35.243:9.3: They hear a sound … smell an odor … taste a flavor … feel a touch …
sn35.243:9.4: cognize a phenomena with the mind. If it’s pleasant they don’t hold on to it, and if it’s unpleasant they don’t dislike it. They live with mindfulness of the body established and a limitless heart. And they truly understand the freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom where those arisen bad, unwholesome qualities cease without anything left over.
sn35.243:9.5: This is called a mendicant who is uncorrupted when it comes to sights cognizable by the eye,
sn35.243:9.6: sounds … smells … tastes … touches … phenomena cognizable by the mind.
sn35.243:9.7: When a mendicant lives like this, if Māra approaches their eye he doesn’t find a vulnerability or get hold of them.
sn35.243:9.8: If Māra comes in through their ear … nose … tongue … body …
sn35.243:9.9: mind he doesn’t find a vulnerability or get hold of them.
sn35.243:10.1: Suppose there was a bungalow or hall made of thick clay with its plaster still wet.
sn35.243:10.2: If a person came with a burning grass torch from the east,
sn35.243:10.8: or from anywhere, the fire wouldn’t find a vulnerability, it would get no foothold.
sn35.243:10.9: In the same way, when a mendicant lives like this, if Māra approaches their eye he doesn’t find a vulnerability or get hold of them.
sn35.243:10.10: If Māra comes in through their ear … nose … tongue … body … mind he doesn’t find a vulnerability or get hold of them.
sn35.243:10.11: When a mendicant lives like this, they master sights,
sn35.243:10.16: and phenomena, they’re not mastered by these things.
sn35.243:10.17: This is called a mendicant who has mastered sights, sounds, smells, tastes, touches, and phenomena. They’re a master, not mastered. Bad, unwholesome qualities have been mastered by them, which are defiled, leading to future lives, hurtful, and resulting in suffering and future rebirth, old age, and death.
sn35.243:11.1: Then the Buddha got up and said to Venerable Mahāmoggallāna:
sn35.243:11.3: It’s good that you’ve taught this explanation of the corrupt and the uncorrupted.”
sn35.243:12.1: This is what Venerable Mahāmoggallāna said,
sn35.243:12.3: Uplifted, the mendicants approved of what Mahāmoggallāna said.
